low: Device temperature too low may cause condensation formation, risking electronic moisture damage
Cold temperatures slow electronic response times, affecting real-time sensor accuracy
Low device temperature can cause battery performance degradation and reduced monitoring uptime
Temperature drops may affect sensor calibration, leading to inaccurate water quality readings
Cold conditions can cause thermal shock to electronic components during power cycling
Device temperature too low risks ice formation, potentially damaging sensor ports
Low temperature affects display visibility and control panel responsiveness
Cold weather conditions can cause sealant contraction, allowing moisture ingress
Temperature extremes stress power supplies, reducing overall device reliability
Low device temperature may trigger automatic shutdowns to prevent component damage
high: Device temperature too high can cause overheating of electronic circuits and sensors
Excessive heat may fry delicate sensor components, permanently damaging the datalogger
High temperature affects processor performance, causing delayed or inaccurate readings
Overheating can damage battery capacity and lifespan significantly
Heat buildup inside enclosures can melt seals and connectors over time
High device temperature may cause thermal expansion damage to internal electronics
Excessive heat can trigger emergency shutdowns, interrupting critical monitoring
Temperature extremes can evaporate calibration solutions, affecting sensor accuracy
Overheating causes premature aging of circuit components and capacitor failure
High heat risks venting system failure, allowing contaminants into device housing
